revised_title: Handling Stress and Mortalities in African Wild Dogs: Debunking the Hypothesis
tldr: This study investigates the effects of handling on African wild dogs and finds that immobilization and blood sampling do not cause chronic stress or increase the risk of mortalities. The research challenges the hypothesis that handling by researchers led to stress-related reactivation of latent rabies viruses in wild dogs, which resulted in their deaths. The findings support the importance of continued monitoring and active management research programs for the survival of endangered wild dog populations.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Ecology and Conservation
